{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3375369,"name":"Avi","username":"Avi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avi/{size}/214903_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-27T18:42:55.040Z","cooked":"

We currently have near zero simulation. What would you say the different levels are? What should we shoot for? How do get there?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2024-04-27T18:42:55.040Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":82,"reads":240,"readers_count":239,"score":458.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":464732,"topic_slug":"levels-of-simulation-what-should-we-be-going-for","display_username":"Avi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55766,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/levels-of-simulation-what-should-we-be-going-for/464732/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3375393,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-27T19:25:35.943Z","cooked":"

I made this video to help some students get started with elevator code, and I think a single subsystem is a good place to get started. I don’t have comprehensive simulation advice to give; this is a narrow perspective.

Here’s the result of altering it some – converting it to Command-Based with command factory methods: GitHub - FRCTeam695/CommandElevatorSimulation at unsimplify

Things I used this simulation to help with:

  • developing a better understanding of how tuning parameters affect control loops, without risking (or even building) the actual mechanisms
  • writing/iterating upon the control interface (commands)
  • debugging glitches in the output (in far less time – the compilation is quicker)
  • understanding how commands and triggers work (e.g., onTrue vs. whileTrue)
  • refining the outputs used for debugging
  • developing intuition
  • refactoring (especially separating the simulation model from the rest of the code)

But simulation is only as accurate as your robot model – it can’t show you things it doesn’t know about. For that reason, I recommend the model be written and checked by your most experienced programmer(s).

I didn’t have a chance to play with it this year, but have the REV motor controllers done anything with sim this year? Last I looked they basically simed the creation of the controller and that was about it.

We have the “robot simulation is not physics simulation” approach. We use simulation to make sure that the correct commands are running, those commands result in the correct goals being generated, and those goals are sent to the appropriate subsystems where setpoints can be utilized. We report each level of this process to NetworkTables for numerical verification, then visualize the robot pose / subsystem states using Mechanism2ds and AdvantageScope.
